questions.question_text: A company is deploying a file-sharing protocol access a network and needs to select a protocol for authenticating clients. Management requests that the service be configured in the most secure way possible. The protocol must also be capable of mutual authentication, and support SSO and smart card logons. Which of the following would BEST accomplish this task?

discussion.content:
Kerberos Authentication System
This is done automatically with a Windows client joined to the domain, login credentials are sent to the Domain Controller (any of them), and if the LDAP user is correct, the controller automatically provides the TGT along with other tickets needed for file sharing to the client.
keyword: «mutual authentication»

Kerberos is an enterprise authentication protocol that uses the concept of tickets and three-way authentication to enable users and computers to identify themselves and secure access to resources. Composer supports Kerberos as a Single Sign On (SSO) mechanism

Kerberos rocks!
https://www.itprotoday.com/security/comparing-windows-kerberos-and-ntlm-authentication-protocols

questions.question_text:
A company wants to provide centralized authentication for its wireless system. The wireless authentication system must integrate with the directory back end.
Which of the following is a AAA solution that will provide the required wireless authentication?

discussion.content: RADIUS is all in one... where TACCS is split up
RADIUS provides centralized Authentication, Authorization, and Accounting (AAA or Triple A) management.
Remote Authentication Dial-In User Service is a networking protocol that provides centralized authentication, authorization, and accounting management for users who connect and use a network service.
Keep in mind that LDAP is not an authentication protocol, but it does facilitate authentication and resource access.

Answer is D LDAP port 389

Key word back end directory 

Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP) is a client/server protocol used to access and manage directory information. It reads and edits directories over IP networks and runs directly over TCP/IP using simple string formats for data transfer. Directory servers include information about various entities on your network, such as user names, passwords, rights associated with user names, metadata associated with user names, devices connected to the network, and device configuration.

Use LDAP to obtain directory information, such as email addresses and public keys. If you want to make directory information available over the Internet, this is the way to do it. LDAP works well for captive portal authentication. However, LDAP does not implement 802.1X security easily. 802.1X was essentially designed with RADIUS in mind, so 802.1X challenge/response protocols like MSCHAPv2 work well with RADIUS
"centralized authentication for its wireless system", that basically means RADIUS

TACACS+ - Device Authentication 
RADIUS - Network Access

Source: https://www.networkworld.com/article/2838882/radius-versus-tacacs.html

Supporting C Radius which provides centralized AAA solution - Mike Meyers 501:
"Terminal Access Controller Access Control System Plus (TACACS+) A proprietary
protocol developed by Cisco to support AAA in a network with many routers and
switches. It is similar to RADIUS in function, but uses TCP port 49 by default and separates
authorization, authentication, and accounting into different parts.
Both are correct but TACACS+ Is a Cisco proprietary, so the answer is RADIUS.
Most likely RADIUS : see -> https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/difference-between-tacacs-and-radius/#:~:text=TACACS%2B%20provides%20more%20control%20over,in%20RADIUS%20i.e%20more%20secure.

Both are correct but for authentications in this case wireless it would be RADIUS.
TACACS+ is usually used in case of device access and command authorization
Do you really think TACACS+ could be the answer or TACAS+? I know about TACAS and TACAS+ but not about TACACS+! Watch out on the exam

comments.content: the point is we choose C. radius for this question anyway
it dosent spell wrong....tacacs+ is correct spelling
Exactly, RADIUS was designed for wireless. It's what you will typically use for authentication when setting up your WAP. Mike Meyers's video on Sec+

discussion.content: I think because it says wireless authentication, so RADIUS is the correct here.
I think the key here is that it has to talk to the directory backend. Per Gibson, "...it is more common for the RADIUS server to access an LDAP server...."
I think the answer is A- TACAC+

TACACS, TACACS+ is a separate protocol that handles authentication, authorization, and accounting (AAA) services. TACACS+ also uses AAA framework to provide centralized access into a network. The answer should be A

comments.content: no no no nono

discussion.content: Giveaway on this question is 802.1x.

RADIUS Federation - federation includes two or more entities (such as companies) that share the same identity management system. Users can log on once and access shared
resources with the other entity without logging on again. Similarly, it’s possible to create a federation using 802.1x and RADIUS servers.
-Source: Get Certified Get Ahead - Authentication Protocols (p.201)

comments.content:
SHIBBOLETH
Shibboleth (http://shibboleth.net) is an open source implementation of SAML. The main components of Shibboleth are as follows:

•

Identity Provider—supports the authentication of users. The software can be integrated with LDAP, Kerberos, X.509, and other directory and authentication systems.

•

Embedded Discovery Service—allows the user to select a preferred identity provider.

•

Service Provider—processes calls for user authentication by contacting the user's preferred identity provider and processing the authentication request and authorization response. The service provider can be used with the IIS and Apache web servers.

https://www.shibboleth.net/

discussion.content: I understand the answer is Radius because of 802.1x but why isn't it Shibboleth?
802.1x is the key which is related to RADIUS
Federation example: Using your Google logging to access, Tumbler, Pinterest, Udemy ect.. SSO "Single Sign On" over different organization.
RADIUS Federation.
http://www.opus1.com/nac/whitepapers-old/05-federated_auth-lv05.pdf

questions.question_text: Multiple organizations operating in the same vertical want to provide seamless wireless access for their employees as they visit the other organizations. Which of the following should be implemented if all the organizations use the native 802.1x client on their mobile devices?

Ann. An employee in the payroll department, has contacted the help desk citing multiple issues with her device, including:
✑ Slow performance
✑ Word documents, PDFs, and images no longer opening
✑ A pop-up
Ann states the issues began after she opened an invoice that a vendor emailed to her. Upon opening the invoice, she had to click several security warnings to view it in her word processor. With which of the following is the device MOST likely infected?

comments.content: Sensible
I think that you are the only person ive seen take in all the info. Shes displaying symptoms of a llittle bit of everything so i think you are actually right.

discussion.content: I think it is a Backdoor, she had to click several security warnings. I read that a backdoor can be used to install additional malware (Adware, Spyware, Ransomware, etc). In this case, she gets popups (adware), her pc is slow (rootkit), cant open files (cryptomal) seems to be the case? Please correct me if I am wrong.

comments.content: Seriously?? Crypto malware is when files are locked

"images no longer opening" 
also, "emailed to her" that is how most Backdoors are transferred as a .EXE
"she had to click several security warnings"
'files are no longer opening'
The wording of "A pop-up" lead me to believe that there is only one pop-up which is most likely a Ransomware massage to pay up!

Crypto-money, this is not an account logout and asking for ransom(money)
Rootkit - The attacker didn't get a root access
Spyware- This is not an attack just spying like keylogger
The best option in backdoor

discussion.content: D is wrong, it should be B.
backdoor

comments.content:
https://www.professormesser.com/security-plus/sy0-501/ransomware-and-crypto-malware/

"These days, however, there is an entire new generation of malware called crypto-malware. This is ransomware that encrypts all of the data on your computer and holds that data for ransom. It’s going to encrypt all of your data files."

discussion.content: There's a bit of confusion about crypto malware in this thread. Guys, crypto malware is completely different than ransomware. It's a malware that uses up your computer's computing resources to mine for crypto currency. Basically, it slows down your computer. So yeah, my best bet is B: Crypto-malware.
Seems as if B is the correct consesus answer, but two quizzes show D to be valid. Idk.

Hi, I do work at security vendor and dealing everyday with backdoors and other types of malware. I can swear I've never seen backdoor performing mentioned actions. It does the opposite, it's quiet and does not affect anything on the system unless someone uses the backdoor in the meantime. However, ransomware is not likely as well, since it is not mentioned.
Damn it Ann

comments.content: Plenty, but you can tell when it's wrong because a lot of ppl will discuss it in this comment section

discussion.content: How many incorrect answers have you come upon?
Look up Crypto-malware. It states it's a kind of ransomware. So, unless the question mentions something about holding information hostage or wanting some money, the answer couldn't be crypto-malware.

comments.content: I'm sorry but crypto malware is completely different than ransomware. Crypto-malware is a malware using up your computer computing power to mine for crypto currency.

discussion.content: Answer is "D". Signs of a Trojan/Backdoor virus include: Desktop & Browser Popups, Slow Computer, and Applications that Won't Start.

I think backdoor is correct. We can see several issues and not just one. I agree with Chief123's explanation and didn't think like that at first. Since the backdoor is accessible, the attacker can easily enter the system or gain illicit access.
I think it is spyware because Crypto malware just encrypt the data. But with spyware she can get advertisements and her computer will be slow as well.

comments.content: Crypto-malware has pop ups to instruct victims how to pay for decryption.

discussion.content: what is the correct answer? , some people say it is right and some say it is wrong, why cant moderators or examtopics.com provide proper explanation for answer, it is really confusing
Do you get INfected with a back door, or Affected with one? This is Crypto Malware that MAY have used a back door for access...
Worst ending to a question ever, could be B if it asks how did the device get infected, or D if its asking the current state of infection.
Believe it should be B, unless wording issue, if meant how this attack occurred...

I thought B too, then read this -a backdoor attack, a program or service is placed on a server
to bypass normal security procedures.Believe question wording is tricky. - D

She is not able to open files -> coz the are encrypted. Slow performance coz it takes lots of cpu power to encrypt stuff. Pop up probably displays the h4x0r’s btc address Spyware, rootkit or backdoor supposed to
be stealth so no popups.

Ans: B
Symptoms is crypto malware albeit ransom, however if you read how it got to Ann’s laptop, it’s all pointing to backdoor

This one should not even be up for debate, it is clearly crypto-malware. the crypto-malware may be using a backdoor, but all the symptoms point to a crypto-malware. Crypto-malware addresses the symptoms, and the cause could be from a known exploit that wasnt patched (which is not considered a backdoor) or it could come from a backdoor. A backdoor is only one possibility while crypto-malware covers all possibility. The mods should change this one.

Malware symptoms that may mean your computer is infected:
Very slow start-up
Slow Internet performance
The browser may not respond or close unexpectedly
Your homepage is changed
Pop-up windows start popping up with much greater frequency
You see signs of email activity that you didn’t send
Random messages, sounds, or music start to appear
There seems to be a lot of network activity when you are not using the network
The available memory on your computer is lower than it should be
Programs or files appear or disappear without your knowledge
File names are changed

comments.content: wrong, it mentioned that word docs, pdfs etc no longer opening, means encrypted

discussion.content: The answer is D. Crypto-malware is a type of ransomware that encrypts users data. Encryption is not mention in this question

The key here is "Pop up" probably displays the Crypto Locker app and address. Spyware, rootkit or backdoor supposed to be stealth so no "popups".
B Crypto-Malware

discussion.content:
To me D is correct.
The reasons:
A. Spyware ( no harm to pc vrs slow performance seen )
B. Crypto-malware (no demands of money seen .. vrs security warnins )
C. Rootkit ( software tools programmed to hide certain objects vrs visible behavior) 
D. Backdoor ( One of the most dangerous types of Trojan )

According to the Professor Messer outline, Crypto-malware is a new generation of ransomware. Which means that someone is requesting payment of something so Crypto-malware isn't correct. So the next best answer is backdoor.
Since she cannot any longer to open files, most likely they are encrypted by malware. So it is B - crypto-malware
B. Crypto-malware in my opinion is the correct one

comments.content: Which is which B or D?
Never said she couldnt get into the files. Simply states she had to click through several popus before viewing. D is the correct answer.

B. Crytpo-malware.

crypto malware baby
B, Crypto-malware.

B. Crypto-malware

Credit to the owner:
She is not able to open files -> coz the are encrypted. Slow performance coz it takes lots of cpu power to encrypt stuff. Pop up probably displays the h4x0r’s btc address Spyware, rootkit or backdoor supposed to be stealth so no popups.

Should be c. Crypto malware. Can’t open any files that store your important information. Probably encrypted. Then rootkit,spyware and backdoor program should all run quietly and stealthily in the background. Pop up is typical for crypto malware, i.e. ransomware. They will inform you to send money to them on the pop up.

It should be crypto Mal ware. If it was spyware it would say something about finding text files/docs with things she typed. The question does not state any of that, spyware from what I studied does not have pop up. 
It is not rootkit as the question mentions nothing about hidden proceses. 
Not sure how backdoor is even relevant. There could be a backdoor but that does not explain why docs not opening and why there is a pop or slowness. 
Hence it should be Cryptomalware. Since it probably encrypted the docs and the pop up is the ransome and offcourse all 3 make a computer slower.

comments.content: nah fam, Crypto-Malware is a type of Ransomware. Specifically it allows your computer to continue running but displays "pop-ups" telling you that we (the bad guys) have your data and you no longer access/ "open" any of those files. B is definitely the right answer.

"The crypto-malware class of ransomware attempts to encrypt data files on any fixed, removable, and network drives". Source: The Official CompTIA Security+ Study Guide (Exam SY0-501): 2019 Update. I'll be going with B.
i'd disagree, crypto malware is utilising your system resources to mine coin for someone else.

choices.B: Run a malware scan on the CEO's workstation
choices.D: Disconnect the CEO's workstation from the network
choices.A: Call the CEO directly to ensure awareness of the event

questions.question_text:
An incident response analyst at a large corporation is reviewing proxy log data. The analyst believes a malware infection may have occurred. Upon further review, the analyst determines the computer responsible for the suspicious network traffic is used by the Chief Executive Officer (CEO).
Which of the following is the best NEXT step for the analyst to take?

comments.content: CompTIA exams are fairly disconnected from real life
CEO is likely not in residence at his office, you dont have his number and he hires people to keep problems like this out of his hair and off his damn mind. THINK! Before you get fired!
Well, CEO doesn't sit on their computer all day like a normal employee.

discussion.content: In real life, nobody would disconnect the CEO's computer from the network without notifying him/her first.
My name says it all with this one.
Why are you all so scared of the CEO? He/she should thank you for stopping the attack. Have some balls, maybe you'll be promoted.
I will do it but I will have on PC already available with the latest patches so CEO will have an available PC to continue with his workload.

It's questions like these why Cyber professionals don't think too highly about these certs only recruiters need them to separate the wheat from the chaff. It's just an exam folks we all know real life doesn't work like this.

comments.content: Of course not...but the point of the exams is to give you a solid foundational background so you can work through incidents like these should you ever come across them in real life.

discussion.content: Going with A. Saw this question in quizlet. search (good Question +2) in quizlet. I think the question are from this site>. Also D seems to be something you would not do.

comments.content: I appreciate the quizlet menion. Thank you.

Malware Removal (scenario)

 Identify and research malware symptoms. ...
 Quarantine the infected systems. ...
 Disable System Restore (in Windows). ...
 Remediate the infected systems. ...
 Schedule scans and run updates. ...
 Enable System Restore and create a restore point (in Windows). ...
 Educate the end user.
thanks. i needed this

discussion.content:
*Disconnects computer from network*
*CEO Calls*
"Bruh, why you disconnect my sh**."
Technician: "Because I am IT."
CEO: "True".

I believe the given answer 'D' (disconnect) is the answer they're looking for. They're referring to the incident response steps. 1) Identification 2) Containment

I'm not saying I'd be ballsy enough to do it in real life - but it would be the correct answer and in line with CompTIA objectives.

comments.content: Even in real life its the way to go.contain the situation before calling the CEO.whats the essence of trying to call him and the malware is busy spreading the entire network which might even lead to DOS attack? the first thing to do is to contain or isolate the problem .

discussion.content: follow the supplied answer - and then YOU ARE FIRED!

comments.content: The supplied answer is the best approach even in real life. your job isnt to satisfy the CEO its to secure and maintain operations. its like providing professional driving to a boss and during an emergency on the highway u have to consult him before saving a crash. never heard before
Pass the exam to get the job only to get fired for using knowledge from the exam lol.

discussion.content: I just believe, following the response process, the next thing to do after identifying the source is to contain the incident. in this case, disconnecting the node from the network will be part of the containment process. I agree with the answer choice D. you can call the CEO later and better be sure there was an actual threat or your reputation is toast.

We know these could be the questions of the exam but do we know that these are also the correct answers? I will go for A in the exam... You will not disconnect a computer from the network if you are not 100% sure and analyst is not in this question

comments.content: My vote fore the answer given, D. You absolutely would disconnect any w/s from the network per company policy, esp in light of resent ransomware events. There would be a proper severity incident, likely with very high severity and a tag "VIP" of some sort, which would require immediate action AND contacting the user. In this case, an analyst or the person who has the IM would contact his manager who would contact AVP or VP who then will contact the CEO. In many large companies low level support would not be even allowed to talk to VPs/CEOs directly, but would be required to take immediate action per policy.
its a network + objective but you gotta disconnect it from the network
well... you wouldnt calll the CEO neither... all this answers are wrong

discussion.content: it says "may have" so he hasnt fking identified it yet
This is such a non-realistic, silly, question. CompTIA question writers must be living on Mars....No one would disconnect the CEO's comp from network!

comments.content: First time commenting; not sure the correct answer but at our company before we had VDI disconnecting workstations was exactly what our policy was. I’m going with D

SO he thinks its malware! Common sense would tell you to unplug it(the ethernet, not the damn PC power source) and then run the Malware scan. In a large corp, you will not waltz into a CEO office, but if they know you as the security guy, and you rool up to his secretaty and explain what you have found, it is likey they let you ion, or put you on their shoulders and carry you(like a champion) into the office to stop the attack that they will be likely to believe will kill and destroy everything the know and love

Ok, I changed my mind after reading this article-(https://www.exabeam.com/incident-response/steps/)
Contain and recover – A security incident is analogous to a forest fire. Once you’ve detected an incident and its source, you need to contain the damage. This may involve disabling network access for computers known to be infected by viruses or other malware (so they can be quarantined) and installing security patches to resolve malware issues or network vulnerabilities.

discussion.content: what if disconnection makes things worse? identify and then containment? Ain't that the order?
